Mrs. B. is a grocery seller out of her house in Krangpophlaek Village in Pursat Province, Cambodia. She sells a variety of products such as food ingredients, cakes, candy, oils, pork, etc. She is married to Sophat, 43, who is a rice farmer. And she has five children, two of whom are married. 

In order to grow her business, to increase  her grocery inventory, B. would like to ask for a loan to purchase more grocery inventory to sell. She expects the loan will improve her business and income.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery inventory to sell

loans.name: Phok

texts.en:
Mrs. N., 28, is a rice farmer, while her husband, Mr. Houy, is a carving-wood seller. The young couple has two children, and both are still young. The parents both work hard every day to support their own family. Her husband carves wood from the forest and sells to customers by transporting to customers' home. He uses a buffalo cart to transport but he rents it from a neighbor.

To reduce the cost for renting the cart, N. would like to ask for a loan to purchase two buffaloes to use as transportation.

loans.use: to purchase two buffaloes to use as transportation

loans.name: Ya

texts.en: Mr. O., 41, is a blacksmith in his village in Pursat Province, Cambodia. He started the business in 1991 and now can earn around US$ 5 per day. His wife, Mrs. Yum, is a housewife and cooks food for the family. His business is going well because he is skilled and customers believe  in the quality of what he has made. He has one child whom he loves so much. To expand his business, O. would like to request a loan to purchase more raw materials for his blacksmith business.

loans.use: to purchase more raw materials for his blacksmith business

loans.name: Pok

texts.en: Mrs. Y., 45, grows vegetables to sell in the market and lives in Roleap Village in Pursat Province. Her husband sells carving wood that he brings from the forest, using an oxen-cart for transportation. Y. has eight children, and all of them are still single. One daughter is employed as a garment worker and one son is a construction worker. In his current business, her husband rents oxen from neighbors, so Y. needs a loan for her husband to purchase two oxen. Y.'s husband is shown in the photo because she was not available for photographing.

loans.use: to purchase two oxen

loans.name: Thuy

texts.en: T. is a rice farmer who lives in Churomseam Village in Pursat Province, Cambodia. Her husband is raising pigs to sell and has a rice mill to provide milling services in the village. The young couple does not yet have any children and works hard to generate revenues for their own family. Normally T.'s neighbors come to her house bringing rice to grind and she charges money or rice for her service. The business is going well but currently her rice mill is broken. Hence, T. needs a loan to purchase a new rice mill.

loans.use: to purchase a new rice mill

loans.name: Ham

texts.en: Mrs. B. is a 25-year-old rice farmer who also grows vegetable crops and lives in Pursat Province, Cambodia. She works growing rice with her husband; they just recently got married and do not yet have any children. The young couple work hard every day with the farming. For another source of income, B. would like to request a loan to purchase piglets to raise to sell. She would use any remainder buying fertilizer for her vegetable crops.

loans.use: to purchase piglets to raise to sell

loans.name: Reynalda De Los Angeles

texts.es: Doña Reynalda tiene 43 años de edad, habita en Hialeah II etapa en la ciudad de Managua, casada y con tres hijos de 13, 14,16 años ambos niños estudian en el colegio del barrio, su esposo es comerciante y administra un kiosco de un colegio, en donde vende comida rápida, la Sra. Reynalda tiene una pulpería y vende en su casa por las noches fritanga,  tiene nueve años de experiencia, inicio con capital propio ofertando pocos productos, y ha venido creciendo y mejorando su situación económica de su familia, con esta solicitud es la novena que ha sido de gran apoyo para su negocio, con este préstamo quiere comprar productos para surtir la pulpería y ofertar a sus clientes la variedad. Sus planes a corto plazo es  comercializar  nuevas variedades de productos y obtener nuevos clientes, a si como dar educación  y un futuro a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Doña Reynalda is 43 years old. She lives in Hialeah II Etapa, in the city of Managua. She is married and has three children of 13, 14, and 16 years of age. These children study in the neighbourhood high school. Her husband is in sales and operates a kiosk in a school, where he sells fast food. Doña Reynalda has a general store and from her home, she sells fritanga (grill food) in the evenings. She has nine years of experience. She began with her own capital, selling a few products, and has continued growing and improving the economic situation of her family. This request is the ninth that have been a huge help for her business. With this loan she wants to buy products to stock the general store and offer her clients variety. Her short term plans are to sell new product varieties and to get new clients, and so give education and a future to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products to stock Doña Reynalda's general store

loans.name: Maria Martha

texts.es: Doña Maria es gerente de una tienda desde hace cinco años, tiene 57 años de edad, y reside en  barrio de Memorial Sandino, tiene una hija de 23 años de edad, que esta en la universidad, anteriormente se desempeñaba en ventas pero con su buen desempeño la promovieron a gerente, lo cual se siente sastifecha por sus logros, su esposo trabaja en una empresa privada de asesor administrativo y siempre ha tenido su apoyo, la Sra. Martha ha hecho tres préstamo en Afodenic en los cuales ha invertido en las mejoras de la vivienda, con este préstamo va a comprar materiales de construcción para construir la cocina  y estar cómoda y gozar de una vivienda digna.  Sus objetivos es segur remodelando su casa para dejarle un buen patrimonio a su hija, a si como seguir apoyándola con sus estudios
texts.en:
Doña Maria has been the manager of a store for the past 5 years. She is 57 years old, and she lives in the neighbourhood of Memorial Sandino. She has a daughter who is 23 years old who is in university. Previously, she worked as a saleswoman, but her good work promoted her to manager, which makes her feel happy for her achievements. Her husband works in a private business of administrative consultants and she always has his support. Sra. Martha has had three loans with AFODENIC in which she invested in improving her home. This loan would go to buying construction materials to construct a kitchen and to be more comfortable and to enjoy a dignified home. Her objectives are to remodel her home to give a good patrimony to her daughter, and so continue to help her with her studies.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials for the kitchen

loans.name: Guissella Ivania

texts.es: La sra: Guissella  habita en el barrio de Hialeah II etapa en la ciudad de Managua, tiene 37 años  de edad, casada y con tres hijos de 1,7,  y 13 años de edad,  doña Guissella junto a su esposo han trabajado mucho pues por la mala situación económica el tuvo que irse al extranjero para ahorrar dinero y poder ayudar a su familia,  con las remesa que le enviada pues paga los estudios de las niñas, y compro una finca con una pareja de vaca que se han venido reproduciendo pues su negocio es la venta de leche y cuajada que ella elabora en su casa de habitación y las remesas mensuales que recibe, son cinco años de experiencia y espera seguir adelante, para cumplir sus metas de terminar de hacer su casa, esta es su cuarta solicitud la cual va a invertir en infraestructura en la compra de materiales de construcción para repellar las paredes la su casa . Sus planes  es conseguir un buen financiamiento que le permita comprar más ganado para aumentar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Doña Guissella lives in the neighbourhood Hialeah II Etapa, in the city of Managua. She is 37 years old, married, and has three children of 1, 7 and 13 years of age. Doña Guissella and her spouse have worked hard because of the poor economic situation he had to go overseas in order to save money and to be able to help his family. With the remittances that he sends they were able to pay for the studies of her daughters, and to buy a farm with a pair of cows that have reproduced. Thus, her business is the sale of milk and curd which she makes in her home, and the monthly remittances that she receives. She has five years of experience and she hopes to move ahead in life, to meet her goals of finishing her home. This is her fourth loan which she has invested in infrastructure, in the purchase of construction materials to repair the walls of her home. Her plan is to continue good finances that will allow her to purchase more livestock and increase her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials to fix her home

loans.name: Melania Del Socorro

texts.es: Doña Melania trabaja desde hace mucho tiempo en casas particulares dando sus servicios de domesticas, pues es un trabajo cansado pero tiene que apoyar a su familia, tiene 44 años de edad, y reside en el barrio de Memorial Sandino en la ciudad de Managua,  su esposo se desempeña como mecánico automotriz, sus planes es poder terminar de construir su casa, con las solicitudes que Afodenic le ha brindado han sido de gran beneficios ya que poco a poco ha ido mejorando su casa, esta es la novena solicitud la cual es para comprar materiales de construcción para terminar de hacer su vivienda ya que parte de la vivienda es de zinc y  quiere brindarle seguridad y bienestar a sus hijos. Sus planes es poder tener un negocio propio en su casa y a si ver mas por su familia.
texts.en:
Doña Melania has worked for a long time in homes, where she provides domestic services. It is hard work, but she has to help her family. She is 44 years old, and she lives in the neighbourhood Memorial Sandino in the city of Managua. Her husband works as an automotive mechanic. Her plans are to finish the construction of her home. With the loans from AFODENIC that have been a great benefit already, she has little by little improved her home. This is the ninth loan she has asked for which is to buy construction materials to finish making her home, and the part of the home is of zinc and she wants to offer safety and to benefit her children. Her plans are to have her own business in her home, and to see more of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials to finish Melania's home

loans.name: Lilliam Del Socorro

texts.es: Lilliam, una joven comerciante que comenzó su propio negocio de venta de mariscos  hace ya tres años por iniciativa propia con la ayuda de su esposo. Tiene 29 años de edad, casada con un hijo de 7 años estudiante de primaria, residente de La Comarca sabana grande en la ciudad e Managua. Entre sus planes esta el obtener más ingresos para poder mejorar su vivienda y de esta manera lograr un mejor estilo de vida para ella y su familia. Para llevar a cabo sus metas esta solicitando  un préstamo con un periodo  de devolución de ocho meses, que le permitirá la compra de más producto y así obtener más ganancias y cubrir  la demanda. Gracias a la ayuda que le brinda AFODENIC, lograra su anhelo.
texts.en:
Lilliam is a young shop keeper who started her own business selling seafood three years ago on her own initiative and with the help of her husband. She lives in the Sabana Grande area of the city of Managua, Nicaragua, is 29 years old and married with a 7 year-old son who is in primary school. One of her goals is to increase her income, which would enable her to make improvements to her home and therefore provide a better quality of life for her and her family. For her to achieve her goals, she requests a loan on a repayment term of eight months, which will allow her to buy more goods and therefore increase profits and meet demand. Fortunately, with the help of AFODENIC, she will realise her dream.

Translated from Spanish by Sara Roden-Scott, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy materials to repair her home

loans.name: Xiomara Del Carmen

texts.es: La Sra. Xiomara es una mujer dedicada a la venta de cosméticos desde hace tres a años, anteriormente tenia una pulpería pero casi no obtenía las ganancias lo cual decidió cambiar de negocio ala venta de cosmético que es mas rentable da al crédito y al contado les ofrece a las jóvenes de oficina y al publico en general, tiene 38 años de edad, y reside en los Laureles Norte en la ciudad de Managua, casada y con dos hijos que estudian,  esta es la quinta solicitud en Afodenic pues ha trabajado con estos financiamiento para agrandar su capital de trabajo, con esta solicitud de prestamos es para seguir invirtiendo en productos cremas, pinturas, perfumes, toallas entre otros producto que son de necesidad diaria del cliente. Sus planes es poder hacer un modulo en un lugar rentable, hacer mejoras en su casa y apoyar a sus hijos con los estudios.
texts.en:
Mrs Xiomara has been dedicated to selling cosmetics for three years. She used to own a local store but it only just made enough profit and therefore she decided to change her business to selling cosmetics, which is more profitable and she can sell her products for both cash and on credit. She sells them to young office workers and to the general public. She is 39 years old, lives in Los Laureles Norte, in the city of Managua, Nicaragua and is married with two children who are studying. This is the fifth loan she has requested from AFODENIC and she has been using the funds to increase the capital of her business. With this loan, she will continue to invest in, among other products, creams, makeup, perfume and towels, all of which her customers require on a daily basis. Her plans are to be able to set up shop in a profitable area, improve the conditions of her home and support her children with their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Sara Roden-Scott, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics such as: make-up and perfume to supply her business

loans.name: Jackeline

texts.es: Doña Jackeline tiene 31 años de edad, casada con dos hijos de 2 y 5 años de edad, habita en Waspan Norte en la ciudad de Managua, su esposo trabaja en ventas de verduras en los departamento lo cual tiene que viajar mucho kilómetros para vender, ella se ha esforzado en apoyarlo ya que todo esta caro y hay que ver por los niños, vende fritanga y hace rifas, estas ventas la hace ambulante y le resulta agotador pero al final del día con su venta terminada se siente contenta, este negocio lo inicio con liquidación del trabajo anterior que tenia en zonas franca, esta es su primer solicitud en Afodenic la cual va invertir en la instalación de aguas negras y la compra de un inodoro para estar mas higiénica con su familia ya que tiene una letrina que ya esta casi llena, sus planes es terminar de hacer su casa ya que es de zinc y desea una mejor vivienda para mejor seguridad de su familia, también desea establecer un lugar fijo donde poner su venta de fritanga donde pueda captar sus clientela.
texts.en:
Mrs Jackeline is 31 years old, married with two children aged 2 and 5 and lives in Waspan Norte, in the city of Managua, Nicaragua. Her husband works as a greengrocer, selling his produce among the various districts of the city and therefore has to travel many kilometres. She has made a real effort in supporting him, now that everything is expensive and they have to provide for their children. She sells fried snacks and organises raffles, which means she has to travel around. This leaves her exhausted but by the evening, when she finishes her selling for the day, she feels satisfied. She started this business with a settlement from the previous job she had in the duty-free zone of the city. This is the first loan she requests from AFODENIC and she will use it to install a sewage system and toilet in her house, providing more hygienic living conditions for her family because at the moment, they only have a latrine that is almost full. Her plan is to also complete the building of her house, which at present is made of zinc and to improve her home, making it more secure for her family. Finally, she aims to establish a fixed place from where she can sell her fried snacks and gain more customers.

Translated from Spanish by Sara Roden-Scott, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy piping in order to install a sewage system and toilet

loans.name: Edmundo Rodolfo

texts.es: El señor Edmundo Blass tiene la edad de 48 años habita en San Juan de la concepción, el  viudo tiene a su cargo un hijo varón de 18 años el cual le ayuda con el trabajo de agricultura, los planes hacia su familia es mejorar las condiciones de vida; desde hace veinte años se dedica a la agricultura, la mayor dificultad que se le presenta es la falta de financiamiento ya que esto a afectado la calidad de producción, el inicio por la necesidad de obtener recursos. Los planes hacia un futuro son mejor todas las condiciones a su finca. Don Edmundo solicita este préstamo para invertir en insumos agrícolas como: fertilizante, venenos  para poder vender bien su cosecha
texts.en:
Mr Edmundo Blass is 48 years old and lives in San Juan de la Concepcíon. He is a widow and is responsible for his 18 year-old son, who helps him with his farming business. His plan is to improve the quality of life for him and his son. He has dedicated the last 20 years of his life to his farming business and the greatest difficulty for him has been the lack of funds, the need of more resources from the beginning, which as a result, has affected the quality of his produce. His plan for the future is to improve the conditions of his farm. Mr Edmundo requests this loan so that he can invest in agricultural supplies, such as fertiliser and pesticides, which will enable him to sell better quality crops.

Translated from Spanish by Sara Roden-Scott, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To obuy agricultural supplies to increase production and sell crops at a better price

loans.name: Marilu

texts.es:
Doña Marilu O. esta agradecido por su gran apoyo que le brindaron en su anterior crédito el cual su negocio ha crecido mucho.
Ella solicita su cooperación para este nuevo préstamo ya que desea invertir le al negocio mercancía como (Verduras, frutas, carnes y lácteos), ya que sus clientes se lo están pidiendo que venda estos productos, porque es el único negocio de la colonia.
 Así tendrá más ingresos a su negocio y posterior mente para la familia.
texts.en:
Marilu O. is grateful for your considerable help with her previous loan thanks to which her business grew greatly. She is asking for your help with this new loan which she wishes to invest in goods for her store, such as vegetables, fruit, meat and cheese. Her clients are asking for these products and she is the only store in the area. This will create more income for her business and later for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy goods for her store

loans.name: Evelia

texts.es:
La señora Evalia H. es madre soltera se ha dedicado a cuidar de sus hijas a darles lo mejor  ya que una de ellas, ya tiene su propia familia que son dos niños de pequeña edad, los cuales viven con doña Evalia en su casa.
Desea quiere que sus nietos tengan un lugar seguro don de vivir, por lo cual empezó la construcción de dos cuarto pero por el momento no cuenta con el capital necesario para poder terminar la mejora y así su hija y nietos tengan su propia vivienda.
texts.en:
Evalia H. is a single mother who has dedicated herself to caring for her daughters, giving them the best. One of her daughters now has her own family, two young children, who live with Evalia in her home. She wants them to have somewhere safe to live and so she started building two rooms but does not have enough money at this time to finish the home improvements so that her daughter and grandchildren can have their own living space.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To complete the building of two rooms in her home.

loans.name: Sharif

texts.en:
Sharif U., an educated, married man, has worked in agriculture for more than 10 years. With plenty of land available for cultivation, this hard-working man is requesting a loan to buy more seeds and ready his land for cultivation. Sharif U. is striving for success as a farmer to support his family and help build a better future for his children and he has requested 40000 (AF) as an individual loan.

He would like to thank everybody supporting him and hopes to continue his partnership with both Kiva and AFSG in the years to come.

loans.use: buying seeds and preparing his land

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: M. is a widowed rice farmer with two children who lives in Phsaleu Village in Pursat Province, Cambodia. Growing rice is the main source of income for her  and she has been farming since 1990. Her daughter, Miss Chansy, 20, works growing rice with M. and they work hard every day to support themselves. She also cares for her elderly parents. Normally, she plows farmland, renting oxen from neighbors and paying a high rent. Hence, she wants to own oxen to use for her business but she lacks money to carry this project out. She would like to ask for a loan to purchase two oxen.

loans.use: to purchase two oxen for farming

loans.name: Ouch

texts.en:
S., 44, works raising pigs and poultry to sell in her village of Sthaney in Pursat Province, Cambodia. She has been raising small livestock since 2005. Her husband is a staff member of an NGO who gets a salary of US$ 100 per month. She has five children, all of whom are teenagers; she is responsible for caring for them.

To increase her income by adding more pigs and chickens, S. would like to request a loan to purchase more piglets and chicks to raise. She expects the loan to help by improving her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase more piglets and chicks to raise

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Mrs. S. is a 61-year-old rice farmer and grows vegetable crops to sell. She lives in Spean Village in Pursat Province, Cambodia. She has been growing rice as a source of income to cover her expenses since 1979. With this experience, she works hard with her husband, Mr. Khon, 61 years old. S. has five children, three of whom are married; two are single. One of her children is employed as a construction worker who can help to support a part of the family and another one works farming with her.

To make her farming business easier and alleviate her physical labor, she needs a loan to purchase an ox; she will use any remainder to purchase seed and fertilizer.

loans.use: to purchase an ox and, possibly, seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Hedayatullah

texts.en:
Hedayatullah is married. He lives with his own family. He is working in agriculture. He has been involved in this business for a long time. He got his first-cycle loan and used it for his business and until now he is furthering his business. Now he plans to enlarge his business. He wants to take out his second-cycle loan.

Therefore he has requested an individual loan of 40,000 Afghanis with a term of 25 months to enlarge his business and complete his stock and buy some seeds for his land. He would love to be a good business dealer in the future. He is happy. Hedayatullah plans to open a retail food shop in Jalalabad city in the next 5 years. He tries his best to open a shop with his income. He wants to say that without this loan it would be impossible to get his business to be its best and he hopes that he is going to be the best in the future.

loans.use: buying seeds and necessary things for his land

loans.name: Prom

texts.en: Mr. T. is a rice farmer who lives in Vatloung Village in Pursat Province, Cambodia. He is 56 years old and works building Cambodian-style houses, while his wife is a rice farmer as well as growing vegetables to sell. Since getting married, T. has not yet had any children and he cares for his elderly father, living with the family in their home. Growing rice  is the main source of income for his family. Normally, Mr. T. farms by renting oxen to plow his farmland and now he want to own oxen for himself. Hence, T. would like to ask for a loan to purchase two oxen.

loans.use: to purchase two oxen

loans.name: Phach

texts.en: Mr. Y., 39, is a rice farmer as well as an oxen trader. Normally, he finds oxen and buys them from villagers at a negotiated price and keeps them to fatten for while to sell at a higher price for profit. He started this business in 1998, while his wife, Mrs. Kimhoeurn, 32, works farming rice. He has two children, both of whom are teenagers and attend school. With a view to growing his business, Y. needs a loan to use as capital for oxen trading.

loans.use: to use as capital for oxen trading

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Mr. S., 45, is a rice farmer who lives in Phsarleu Village in Pursat Province, Cambodia. And his wife is a poultry raiser. They both work hard every day at farming rice because it is the main source of income for their family. They have three children, all of whom are teenagers and are enrolled in school. S. often faces difficulties with lacking labor to use for farming, so he rents buffaloes from his neighbors. To avoid rental costs, S. needs a loan to purchase two buffaloes.

loans.use: to purchase two buffaloes to plow his fields

loans.name: Rohullah

texts.en:
This is 35-year-old Rohullah. He is married and lives in Ningarhar province with his family. Rohullah has 2 children, who go to school. His brother works with him in their own agricultural lands and they share a house. After his father died, Rohullah became the responsible person for the household.

Actually, Rohullah is a teacher besides doing farming. He teaches in a public school in the morning, and in the afternoon he works as a farmer in his village. He grows different kinds of vegetables and he sells them in the bazaar. Besides farming, he has got some livestock as well. His small son brings grass for the animals.

Rohullah is a hard-working man for sure, but there are 10 members in his family and supporting that many people with 300 Afghanis (US$ 6) a day in income is almost impossible. He therefore has to expand his business. He thinks that if he buys more livestock and seeds for his lands, he can increase his income. He has requested 30,000 Afghanis as a loan from AFSG. He has decided to buy a cow and with any remaining loan money, he will purchase seeds and pesticide.

Rohullah dreams of the day that he will solve all his economic problems and then concentrate on teaching.

loans.use: Buying a cow and seeds for his land

loans.name: Lao

texts.en: Mrs. C. is a 37-year-old farmer who grows rice and other fruits and vegetables, such as watermelon, pumpkin, and green beans, to sell. Her husband, Mr. Sang, 46, provides musical speakers for wedding parties and ceremonies in his area (pictured here). They have three young teenagers, who all attend school. To increase the family's income, C. requests a loan to expand the number of crops she grows, and to buy piglets to raise.

loans.use: To grow more crops and buy piglets to raise

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en: Mrs. P. is 54 years old, and she lives in Pursat Province, Cambodia. She is married with three children, all of whom are teenagers and in school. Mrs. P. and her husband, Mr. Vong, 61, are rice farmers. The rice crop is the only source of income for the family, so Mrs. P. needs to take care and improve this business. Thus, she is asking for a loan to purchase four oxen to use on her farm.

loans.use: Purchase four oxen

loans.name: Sum

texts.en:
Mr. S. is a 56-year-old rice farmer who lives in Pursat Province, Cambodia. Since 1980, he has been growing rice. Rice is the only source of income for his family. He and his wife work hard every day on the farm, even though they face some difficulties. He has two children living at home; one is studying and the other helps on the rice farm. Three other children are married.

To improve his farming business, S. requests a loan to purchase two young buffaloes, and buy some piglets to raise for another source of income.

loans.use: Purchase two young buffaloes, and buy some piglets to raise for another sources income

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce H. is thirty-two years old; she is married and the mother of four children. All her kids are in school. She has been selling food for the past 13 years to support her family. She sells gari (cassava couscous) and beans with ripe plantains in the community school at Nkawkaw. Gari and beans is a dish enjoyed by many Ghanaians because it contains lots of protein and it is also affordable to buy.

Joyce's business is doing well because she is good at human relations and due to the tasty meals she sells. Her major challenge is when the students are on vacation; this means she must also break for a while. In order not to be idle during school vacations, she wants to expand her operation while students are on vacation by selling in the community market.

Joyce wants this loan to buy foodstuffs such as gari, plantains, beans, charcoal etc. to restock her inventory. It has also been her dream to save more from her business proceeds to pay school fees for her children in school. Joyce belongs to a village bank called ‘Asetenapa’ meaning Good Living. She hopes to receive GHS 400 to make business progress.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs such as gari, plantains, and beans, etc.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther A. is thirty-three years old. She is divorced and has four children, one girl and three boys. All of her children are in the basic school. Being a single parent, Esther says it is very cumbersome providing for her children, and most especially, paying their school fees. Therefore, she needs to work very hard to meet all these demands.

She lives with her children in Bibiani in the Western Region of Ghana. She says her ex-husband does not support the family in any way. Esther A. is a second-hand textiles dealer. She deals mostly in bed sheets and towels. She buys from wholesalers in Kumasi and sells them door-to-door in her community. She also sells on a table top in the local market square. 

Esther wants a loan to buy the textiles in large bales, so that she can trek to other towns to do business. It is her dream to sponsor her children to the tertiary level of education.

loans.use: To buy second-hand textiles in bales

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James A. P. is 63 years old. He is married and the father of five children. He says that, with the help of God, all of his children attend school. 

He owns and operates a grocery shop where he sells items like sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, skimmed powdered milk, and biscuits in his neighborhood of Nkawkaw. With his six years of experience in this business, James has supported two of his children to senior high school. He hopes to send them to the tertiary level.

Fortunately, his business has been positioned at a strategic location in the town where he lives. Because of this, he believes, when he receives extra income, he can serve more customers in the community. Moreover, the surrounding communities do not have big grocery shops like his. 

With the loan, he wants to purchase more assorted drinks, sugar, vegetable oil, and biscuits to increase his inventory. He hopes to improve his savings to support his children in school. 

James belongs to a village bank called Divine. He hopes to receive GH¢400 loan to make his business progress and he would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena B. is thirty-one years old. She is married and has no children at the moment. Helena’s husband works with a cocoa marketing company in the Bibiani township where they live. 

She also runs a supermarket to support her husband. Her shop is located at the lorry station. She has been in business for four years. She sells items such as milo, milk, sugar, bread, and canned fish. Helena buys her goods from wholesalers in the neighboring big cities, such as Kumasi. 

She wants a loan to expand the size of her shop and to buy goods in bulk. It is Helena’s dream to own one of the big supermarket shops in her community.

loans.use: To buy groceries in bulk

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. started selling fish eight years ago in a village in a suburb of Nkawkaw, in the eastern region of Ghana, where she lives. Mary prepares and serves her customers very tasty and good quality fish and many customers buy from her stand. 

She is 52 years old and is married with four children who are currently in school. She wants to use the loan to buy more assorted fishes to increase her sales and income and to support her children’s education and business growth.

Mary buys her fish in Afram Plains directly from the fisher. This helps her to avoid the middlemen who sell at higher prices. She is requesting a loan to buy more fish, because the more she buys, the lower is the cost of each fish. 

Mary belongs to a village bank called ‘Asetenapa,’ which means "good living." She hopes to receive GH¢500 to help her business progres and she would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy more smoked fish

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Christiana A. is thirty-one years old. She is divorced and has three children. All of her children are in junior high school. Christiana says her husband has not helped to provide for their family in any way. She said that this necessitated their break -up. As a result, she works very hard to provide for the family and, most importantly, to pay for her children’s school fees. 

Christiana sells varieties of drinks and mineral water in bottles and cans. She does not own a shop, but she sells door-to-door to houses and through the local market. She buys the drinks from wholesalers in her community. She says that this is not cost-effective. She wants more working capital so that she can buy directly from the manufacturers. 

Christiana wants a loan to order more drinks and mineral water so that she can distribute her wares to more customers.

loans.use: To buy drinks and mineral water in bulk

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa A. started her business fifteen years ago in the village where she lives with her family. Yaa is a food vendor and she prepares and serves what we called ‘Obrayo’ (porridge) and baflot in a community school. Obrayo is prepared from dried maize; this maize is soaked in water for about three days before it is ground but not to the smoothest level. This food or porridge is just like any other porridge but with this one you feel the maize kernels whilst enjoying it. Obrayo can be taken with bread or baflot. It can be eaten either as breakfast or lunch and it is purely carbohydrate food. Apart from this, she also prepares baflot and sells it together with the porridge.

Yaa A. is married with two kids who are currently in school. Through her excellent food standards and moderate price many people buy her food. She is requesting a loan to buy more bags of maize, sugar, milk, flour, margarine, charcoal, etc., so that she can remain in business. Yaa belongs to a village bank called ‘Yonkodo’ which means Best of Friends. She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make her business progress. And she would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: For the purchase of maize, flour, margarine, milk etc.

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en:
Gifty Y., thirty- four, is married with four children. Two of her children are in senior high school while the other two are in junior high school. Gifty says her husband’s business is not booming now. As a result, she works very hard to help provide for the family and most importantly, to pay the children’s school fees.

Gifty sells varieties of drinks and mineral water both in bottles and also in cans. She doesn’t own a store and so hawks her products door-to-door and in people’s work places. She desires to distribute the mineral water in crates to retailers. She therefore wants a loan to achieve this. She procures the drinks from retailers in her community. She wants to procure them directly from the manufacturers in Kumasi where the cost is economical.

loans.use: To buy crates of mineral water

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel B. is 39 years old. He is married and the father of two kids. Currently one is in school whilst the last born is still breastfeeding. Samuel is supportive of his spouse and family through the business he does. He is a car welder in the village where he lives. He sees it as an opportunity to be at home. Samuel went through his apprenticeship 10 years ago in the town of Kumasi in the Ashanti region of Ghana. With that period of experience, hard work, humility and time abound.

He decided to move to his home town to establish his welding shop. Through that period it was very difficult for him to start something on his own because he did not have enough money. He went into farming for a while to gather a small amount of money as start-up capital. What the money could do at that time was to buy wood to erect a shop.

Upon advice from friends who are members of Sinapi Aba Trust, he decided to ask for a loan to make business progress. Though at that period he had started working on customers' cars, coal pots, ovens, etc., he was still faced with financial challenges. Samuel is requesting a loan to buy welding machines, steel plates, and silver plates, among others. He believes this would facilitate his work.

Samuel belongs to a village bank called ‘Asetenapa’ which means Good Living. He hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress. And he would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: For the purchase of silver plates, steel plates, rods, etc.

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah O. is very supportive of her husband; not a lazy woman, she's a very hard-working mother. She is 32 years old, married and the mother of five kids. Through the help of government free compulsory education, four of her kids are in school. She is a multi-business entrepreneur who deals in diverse products such as ice cream, agro-chemicals, and hardware sales and she started all this a year ago in the village where she lives.

Deborah treks to the big town called Kumasi to purchase her goods and retails them to her customers in the village. She is requesting a loan to buy a bulk supply of goods to prevent frequent travel. Deborah wants to buy items like ice cream and agro-chemicals to increase her inventory. Deborah belongs to a village bank called ‘Asetenapa’ which means Good Living. She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress. And she would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: For the purchase of agro-chemical products and hardware for re-sale

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris A. is forty-three years old. She is married and has four children. Currently, two of her children have completed high school while the rest are in the basic school. Her husband is a farmer. He cultivates cash crops such as cocoa and some vegetable crops.

Doris says her husband is trying his best to provide for the family but his income is not enough to provide for the entire family and moreover, to pay the children’s school fees. As a result, it is necessary for her to work to help her husband support the family.

Doris is a second-hand textile dealer. She deals mostly in women's dresses and bedspreads. She buys from wholesalers in Kumasi and hawks her wares to houses in her community. She also sells on a table top in front of her house and in the local market square. She wants a loan to buy textiles in large bales so that she can trek to other towns to do business. She desires to help her husband pay for their children to get to the tertiary level of education.

loans.use: To buy bales of textiles for re-sale

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua A. is 42 years old, divorced and the mother with two children. All her kids are in school. She has been selling food for the past 3 years to take care of her family. She sells gari and beans with ripe plantains in the community school at Nkawkaw. Gari and beans is enjoyed by many Ghanaians because it contains lots of protein and is affordable.

Akua's business is doing well due to her social skills. Her major challenge is that when the students are on vacation she has to break for a while. In order not to be idle during school vacation she wants to expands her operation while students are on vacation.

Akua would like a $400 loan to buy food stuffs like gari, plantain, beans, charcoal to restock her inventory. Her dream is to save more from her business proceeds to take care of children's school expenses. Akua belongs to a village bank called ‘Asetenapa’, meaning Good Living.

loans.use: To buy food stuffs like gari, plantains and beans

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama Owusuaa is 35 years old and married with three children. Currently, all her children are in elementary school. Her husband is a carpenter by profession. He makes furniture such as tables, stuffed chairs, and wardrobes. Ama O. is a second hand textiles dealer. She deals mostly in bedspreads. She buys from wholesalers in Kumasi and hawks them door to door in her community. She also sells on a table top in the market square. Ama would like a loan to buy textiles in large bales so that she can trek to other towns to make business. It is her dream to help her husband sponsor their children to the university level of education.

loans.use: To buy second hand textiles in bales

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes O. is a 53 years old trader.  She is divorced and the mother with two girls. One is married and one is in junior high school. Agnes trades in onions, tomatoes and pepper etc. at a village in Nkawkaw where she lives. Agnes belongs to a village bank called ‘Divine’. She requests a loan to enable her to buy increased stock of tomatoes, onions, pepper to scale up the business. She hopes to increase her savings to support her child's education to give her a future and hope.

loans.use: To buy increased stock of onions, tomatoes and pepper.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort B. is forty years old. She is married and has five children, two boys and three girls. All her children are still in school. Comfort’s husband is farmer. He cultivates food crops such as cassava, plantain and vegetables. Comfort sells doughnuts. She makes it herself and distributes to porridge sellers in her community every morning. She hawks the remainder to houses and finally, goes to the local elementary school to sell the rest to the schoolchildren. Comfort has been in business for four years. She procures her raw materials such as flour, sugar, oil, etc from the nearby shops in her community. Comfort wants to use the loan to procure bags of flour from wholesalers in the big cities where cost is quite economical.

loans.use: To buy oil, bags of flour, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica P. is a 46 year old trader.  She is married and the mother with four children. They all attend school in the village. She trades in onions, tomatoes and pepper etc. in a village at Nkawkaw where she lives. She treks to Kumasi to buy her stock of goods in bulk and sells them in the surrounding towns during their market days. Her business helps two of her kids finish junior high school. She requests a loan to enable her to buy increased stock of tomatoes, onions, pepper to scale up the business. She hopes to increase her savings to support her children's education to give them a future and hope. 

Veronica belongs to a village bank called ‘Divine’. She hopes to receive a $400 loan to grow her business by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To increase her stock of vegetables like onions, tomatoes and pepper etc.

loans.name: Afia

texts.en: Afia A. is 42 years old. She is married and has two children – a boy and a girl. The girl is currently in high school while the boy is in university. Afia lives in Bibiani, a farming/mining community in the Western Region of Ghana. Afia’s husband is a farmer. She is an industrious woman. She sells smoked fish in the local market square to help provide for the family. She buys fresh fish and smokes it herself. She says the cost is economical in this way. She buys the fish from the bigger cold stores in the big cities such as Kumasi at wholesale prices. Afia has been in business for over ten years. She supplies mostly to food vendors in her community. She would like a loan to buy more fish in bulk so that she can sell to more customers.

loans.use: To buy fish in bulk

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter O. is 47 years old, married and the father of four children. Three of them are in high school, studying science, business and visual arts respectively.  The youngest is still breastfeeding. Peter operates a licensed chemical shop in the village where he hails from and where he lives with the family. Peter is the Assembly man in the village.  In Ghana every town, village, city have assembly man. He serves as the mouthpiece for the community through which the community channels their grievances to the chief executive of the entire district. 

The pharmacy shop has been the major source of livelihood for Peter's family. He has being operating the shop for the past six years. He supplies the surrounding villages with pharmaceutical drugs. He rides a bicycle for a long distances to reach surrounding towns. This slows his business down. 
Peter believes buying a motorbike will ease his operations. Peter belongs to a village bank called ‘Divine’.  He requests the loan to buy drugs and a motor bike for efficiency in service delivery.

loans.use: To buy pharmaceutical drugs and a motor bike

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort O. is 37 years old. She is married and has four children. All her kids are still in school. She owns and operates a grocery store, selling items like sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, skimmed powdered milk and biscuits in her neighborhood at Nkawkaw. 

Comfort belongs to a village bank called ‘Rejoice’. She hopes to receive $400 to increase her inventory by purchasing more crates of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of biscuits and other foodstuffs to increase her inventory. She hopes to improve her profits to support her children in school. She believes with her five years experience she would be able to make good use of the loan.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products like cartons of assorted drinks, bags of sugar etc.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena D. is 38 years old. She is married with two children in junior high school. She has been a local manufacturer of palm oil and a baker for years now. Palm oil is produced from palm nut fruits. The palm oil is processed through various stages to obtain the palm oil.  Palm oil is produced is used to prepare many local dishes. Her production is on a small scale due to capital inadequacy to buy machines for the processing.

Abena also bakes bread and supplies them to the surrounding villages. She says this has also slow due to current food prices in the world market. She wants to use the loan to buy more palm nuts in bulk  to produce palm oil in larger quantities. She would also like to buy more flour, sugar, margarine, charcoal etc. so that she can produce more bread and supply them to her customers on regular basis.

Abena believes this loan will help expand her business to support her family and finance her children’s education. 
Abena belongs to a village bank called ‘Asetenapa’ which means "Good Living". She hopes to receive $400 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more palm nuts and baking materials like flour and others.

loans.name: Mr. Leay Soun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Sixteen people living in Krang Thmei village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mr. Leay S. is the 66- year-old village bank president. He and his wife, Mrs. Vang Mao, are farmers who own 1.5-hectare field of land to cultivate rice. In this plantation, they face a problem because they do not have enough money to hire laborers to harvest rice. In order to solve this problem, Mr. Leay S. decided to request a loan for this purpose. He is the father of two children, one of whom is a laborer in the hospital while the other is employed in a garment factory.  

One member of this group loan has an end-of-term loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To request a loan to hire laborers to harvest rice.

loans.name: Hun

texts.en:
Mrs. Hun P., 53, is married and has one child. She and her husband work together on their rice paddy growing rice and some other crops in Prey Chhor district, Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. They started their farming activity in 1980, when they were released and liberated from the Pol Pot regime, a black moment in history for Cambodian citizens, killing nearly three million Cambodian people and completely destroying the whole infrastructure in the entire country.

Hun P. had learned farming skills from her parents since she was 16. After the Pol Pot regime, she moved back to her hometown and started a farming business to support herself. Life was a struggle for her and her husband because they had to restart their farming work, not having many tools and seeds.

At this point, the couple can typically make around US$ 4/day in revenue. With this money, she covers her monthly expenses such as US$ 30 on food, US$ 30 on utilities and US$ 4 on her transportation.

When she learned about CREDIT MFI, a KIVA partnership, Mrs. Hun P. applied for a loan in the amount of $1000 to buy fertilizer and insecticide to increase her output. The loan will give her an opportunity to expand her crops and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and insecticide to increase her output

loans.name: Mr. Sobon Bo Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty-one people who all live in Knong Preaek village in Kandal province make up this village bank. They will use the loan for a variety of purposes, and Mr. Sobon B. is the village bank president. He and his wife, Mrs. H. Teim, sell raw materials which are used to make incense sticks. Since their business is going well, they want to expand it. Thus, Mr. Sobon B. decided to ask for a loan to purchase that material to re-sell. He is 50 years old and the father of six children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school.

One member in this group loan has an end-of-term (EoT) loan and the rest have monthL. payment loans. EoT borrowers are not required to pay aN. principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financialL. able to. Most clients start to make payments maN. months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of onL. 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase more raw materials used to make incense sticks

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Mrs. Un C., is 40, married with two children, and lives with her husband in Phrey Chhor district, Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband work on their rice paddy growing rice for their annual supplies. Besides growing crops, the couple also operate another business performing classical and traditional music. When there is a celebration, a wedding party or ceremony in the community, the person in charge of the celebration will hire them to play the music. Together, the couple can typically earn around US$ 4/day in revenue.

The instruments they need are CD player, microphones, big speakers, and some other instruments. Mrs. Un C. and her husband would like to request this loan from Kiva to purchase more instruments to meet their customer demand.

loans.use: To buy more music instruments to satisfy her customer demand

loans.name: Mrs. Sokhon Khourn Village Bank Group

texts.en: Seventeen people in Knong Preaek village in Kandal province form this village bank and Mrs. Sokhon K. is the village bank president. She buys vegetable to re-sell in the local market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to re-sell. She hopes to increase her income and improve the famiL.'s living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Ruos Kuoch, is a healer in the local village. Mrs. Sokhon K. is 32 years old and the mother of three children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to re-sell

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Lê Thị Hoàn, 28 tuổi,chị đang sống cùng chồng và 1 con nhỏ tại Quảng Xương Thanh Hoá. Hiện tại chị đang kinh doanh săm lốp ô tô còn chồng chị làm nghề lái xe. Với thu nhập 4.000.000 đ/ tháng việc hàon trả vốn của gia đình chị Hoàn cũng rất thuận lợi. 
Chị Hoàn đang mong muốn được vay 5.000.000đ để đầu tư thêm vốn vào công việc kinh doanh của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lê Thị Hoàn - 28 years old - she lives with her husband and small child at Quảng Xương Thanh Hoá. Currently, she has a business selling inner tubes for automotive tires while her husband works as a driver. With an income of 4,000,000 VND per month, their businesses completely repair their loans and is quite profitable. Hoàn is hoping to borrow 5,000,000 VND to reinvest into her family businesses.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business - Automotive Tires and Driver

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi: Chị Trần Thị Mận, 26 tuổi, ở Quảng Xương Thanh Hoá. Gia đình chị có một con nhỏ 5 tuổi. Hiện tại thu nhập của  gia đình phụ thuộc vào công việc chăn nuôi, buôn bán hàng tạp hoá và tiền công làm nghề cắt tóc của chồng với thu nhập  2.000.000/ tháng. Chị mới tham gia vào Quỹ từ tháng 12 năm 2008, chị mong muốn được vay vốn với mức là 5.000.000 để đầu tư vào buôn bán  nhằm tăng thêm thu nhập cho gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Trần Thị Mận - 26 years old - lives in Quảng Xương Thanh Hoá. She has a young child that is 5 years old. Currently, her family's incomes comes from the business of rearing livestock, buying/selling of general goods and her husband's haircutting business with an income of 2,000,000 VND per month. She just joined TYM Fund in December of 2008. She hopes to borrow 5,000,000 VND to invest into their retail business to increase her family's income.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Retail Business

loans.name: Mr. Khom Chhum Village Bank Group

texts.en: Thirteen people living in Knong Preaek village in Kandal province comprise this village bank, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mr. K. C., the 55-year-old village bank president, and his wife, Mrs. Chhuon Hen, are vegetable middlemen. Since their businesses are going well, they want to expand them. Thus, Mr. K. C. decided to request a loan to purchase more vegetables to re-sell. He hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan. He is the father of four children who are employed in a garment factoR..

loans.use: to purchase more vegetables to re-sell

loans.name: Chheng

texts.en:
Chheng V. was born and raised in a farming family. She started growing rice and some other crops in 1980. The output is just sufficient for her household.

Her husband works making string cow and selling them at the market. With his business activity, he can generally make about US$ 4/day in income to support his household. Because of their lack of capital, Chhen V. didn’t have any idea how to make other profit beside working at her rice field.

After learning about CREDIT MFI from one of her neighbors, V. thought of an opportunity to generate additional profit for her household. She would like to take a loan in the amount of US$ 600 to buy rice crops from the growers and re-sell the rice when the price is going up. She believes this will help her increase her income as well as improving her living conditions. (her husband is pictured )

loans.use: To buy rice crops from the growers to re-sell for a profit

loans.name: Mrs. Sovy Vann Villag Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty-four people living in Knong Preaek village in Kandal province comprise this village bank, and they will use their share of the loan for various purposes. Mrs. Sovy V., the 32-year-old village bank president, is a fish seller in the local market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy more fish to re-sell. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family's living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. N. ME. Tech, is a waiter who can make only a small salary to support the family. Mrs. Sovy V. is the mother of a child who is enrolled in the local school.

One member in this group loan has an end-of-term loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. EoT borrowers are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more fish to re-sell

loans.name: Ni Ketut Sudini

texts.id:
Ni Ketut sudini Pada Pinjaman yang pertama di pergunakan untuk menambah modal dalam usaha warungnya, sehingga jumlah macam daganganya bertambah lebih banyak. Ni ketut Kasiani untuk periode pinjaman yang ke dua yang jumlahnya sebesar Rp 5 000 000 Juga akan dipergunakan untuk menambah modal usahanya agar dapat meningkatkan omset penjualanya dan juga keuntungan bersih dari hasil penjualanya.
Ni Ketut Sudini bermagsud untuk melanjutkan pinjaman periode ke dua dengan jangka waktu 12 bulan dengan pembayaran dilunasi pada akhir periode pinjaman. sehingga dengan tambahan modal tersebut mereka dapat meningkatkan jumlah persediaan barang maupun pulsa yang akan di jual sehingga keuntungan yang diperoleh akan lebih meningkat guna penunjang pendapatan keluarganya.
texts.en:
Ni Ketut Sudini used her first loan from Kiva/DINARI to purchase more inventory for her store. She would now like to get a second loan of 5,000,000 Rupiah to help her get quicker turnover of her products and to turn a better profit. Ni Ketut Sudini's second loan would be for a period of 12 months, with a full repayment by the end of that time. With the increase in funding, she will diversify her inventory of products. She hopes this will help pick up the pulse of her business and allow her to use the money to help her family.

Translated from Indonesian by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase funding for her store

loans.name: Sok's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok R., is the leader of the five-member group; all the borrowers live in Svay Dongkom Commune of Siem Reap Province.

Mrs. Sok R. is a 58-year-old widow. She sells lotus flowers for ceremonies. She travels to find the lotus flowers in the ponds far away from her home. She has been running her business for a long time ago. She is responsible for three children; two of them are single and one is widowed. All of her children live with her in the family home. Her widow-child works with her selling lotus flowers. To make the business and family's transportation easier, Sok R. requests a loan to purchase a motorcycle. The loan will help her reduce her business expenses.

The other four borrowers are:

  • Pok C., 40, and a widow. She sells different kinds of flowers and requests a loan to purchase more flowers to sell.
  • Sek S., 44, raises pigs at home and sells flowers. She requests a loan to buy flowers to sell.
  • Sum T. is 40 years old. He is a local construction worker, who requests a loan to buy house repairing. (T.'s wife appears in the photo in his place.)
  • Srey P. is 34 years old and a widow. She sells groceries and she requests a loan to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.use: Purchase a motorcycle for business and family transportation needs

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Mrs. Im S. lives in Sdao Kanlaeng village in Kandal province. She is a grocer who owns a small grocery store in the local village. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy more grocery goods for her inventory. Her husband, Mr. Mech Kim, uses a motorbike with a side-car to transport passengers. Mrs. Im S. is 44 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is a driver while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is also in the picture.

loans.use: to buy more grocery goods for her inventory

loans.name: Saroen

texts.en: Mrs. Saroen S. is 46 years old and she now lives in Preaek Traeng village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. In this plantation, she faces some problems because she does not have much money to buy bean seeds, fertilizer, and fuel for a pump to water to support the field. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy all these things for cultivation. She hopes to increase income and improve the living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Touch Kunthea, is a musician who has been hired by the villagers for wedding ceremonies. Mrs. Saroen S. has three children who are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To request a loan to buy bean seeds, fertilizer, and fuel for cultivation.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Quê năm nay 45 tuổi , gia đình chị có 3 con trong đó có hai con đang tuổi đến trường. Năm 1999 chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn . Đến nay sau 10 năm tham gia Quỹ tình thương gia đình chị đã có thêm nguồn vốn để đầu tư mở rộng chăn nuôi thêm vịt, gà. Hiện tại chăn nuôi cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị với thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ thnág
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay  10.000.000đ để mua thêm 300 con gà giống về nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen thi Q. is 45 years old. She has three children, two of them are in school age. In 1999 she joined the TYM Fund and borrowed money to invest in raising pigs. After 10 years participation with TYM Fund, her family has additional cash to invest in raising ducks and chickens. Currently, raising ducks and chickens is the main source of income for her family with an average monthly income of VND2,000,000.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND10,000,000 to buy additional 300 chickens to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy additional 300 chickens to raise

loans.name: Mech

texts.en: Mrs. Mech P. is a villager in Trapaing Sva village in Kandal province. She is a dessert seller. She is a 48-year-old widow with two children who are employed in a garment factory. Since her children work far from the house, they usually pay much money for motorbike taxi for transportation. Thus, Mrs. Mech P. is requesting a loan to buy a motorbike for her child to go to work. She hopes to reduce her expenses and make it easier for her children to work.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her child to go to work.

loans.name: Sam Art

texts.en: Mrs. Sam Art C. lives in Kouk Trab village, in Kandal province. She is a grocer who owns a small grocery store. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it with this loan, by purchasing more grocery products for her inventory. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family's living conditions. Her husband, Mr. Neal Siphat, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Sam Art C. is 39 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory. The other children attend the local school. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products for her inventory.

loans.name: Tang Sure

texts.en: Mrs. Tang Sure P. is a villager in Kampong Pou village, in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. On this plot of land, she faces some problems because her field is infertile and has a lot of insects. Also, she does not have enough money to hire laborers to work in the field. In order to deal with these problems, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides, and hire laborers to work in the field. Her husband, Mr. Phal Sopheap, is a fisherman. Mrs. Tang Sure P. is 42 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides, and hire laborers to work in the field.

loans.name: Do Thi

texts.vi: Chị  Đỗ Thị Cùng, năm nay 57 tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2003, lần đầu tiên khi chị tham gia chị vay 1000.000đồng để chăn nuôi lợn, gà. Kết quả sau 3 tháng chị được lãi với số tiền là:700.000đ. Hiện nay, với số vốn vay được và đầu tư có hiệu quả, nhà chị có 1 mẫu vườn chuyên trồng rau  và cây ăn quả để bán đời sống gia đình được nâng cao. Vòng vay tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000 để mua thêm 500 cây con giống, mở rộng quy mô làm vườn.
texts.en:
Mrs. Do Thi C. is 57 years old. She joined the Fund in 2003. In the first loan after she joined the Fund, she borrowed VND1,000,000 to raise pigs and chickens. After three months, she had a profit of VND700,000. Currently, with the loans and the effective use of them, she now has a garden of vegetables and fruit trees to sell. The condition of living therefore has improved.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND10,000,000 to buy additional 500 small fruit plants to expand the garden.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy additional 500 small fruit plants to expand the garden.

loans.name: Ha Thi

texts.vi: Chị Hà Thị N., 35 tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 1998 .Gia đình chị có 2 con còn đang đi học. Thu nhập chính của gia đình phụ thuộc vào công việc đi xe ôm của chồng và công việc bán hàng đồ nhựa của chị. Với sự giúp đỡ của chị em trong Cụm và sự nỗ lực của bản thân đến nay  sau 10 năm tham gia Quỹ kinh tế gia đình chị Lệ rất ổn định với thu nhập 2.500.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn 15.000.000 để đầu tư mua thêm hàng hóa về bán.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ha Thi N. is 35 years old. She joined TYM Fund in 1998. She has two children who are in school. Her main source of income comes from her husband's earning as a motorbike cabbie (instead of a car, motorbike cabbies take passengers on motorbikes for a fee) and her retail business of selling plastic goods. With hard work and the help of other members in her loan group, after 10 years, her family's economy has become stable with the income of 2,500,000 per month. She would like to borrow 15,000,000 VND to invest in her retail business.

Translated from Vietnamese by ThienN. Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Trang

texts.en: Mr. Trang N. lives in Thmor Kor village, in Kandal province. He and his wife, Mrs. Keo Srey are farmers who own a small piece of land to cultivate vegetables. With this land, they face an obstacle. They do not have enough money to grow mangoes. Mr. Trang N. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides, and fuel for a pump that can water the mangoes field. He hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan. He is 59 years old and the father of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another is a construction worker. The remaining children attend the local school. His wife is also shown with him in the picture.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides, and fuel for a pump to water the mangoes field.

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi: Chị Lê Thị Lệ, 41 tuổi ở huyện Kim Động. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 1997 . Sau khi tham gia Quỹ với số vốn vay được chị đã mạnh dạn đầu tư mua thêm đất mở rộng quy mô trồng trọt và chăn nuôi của gia đình. Nhờ sự cần cù, chịu khó, sau 11 năm vay vốn từ Quỹ, hiện nay gia đình chị đã có 2 sào bưởi các loại chủ yếu là bưởi Diễn và bưởi năm roi cho thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay với mức vốn là 15.000.000 để đầu tư mua thêm phân bón và cây giống.
texts.en:
Mrs. L. Thi L. is 41 years old. She lives at the province of Kim Dong. She joined TYM Fund in 1997. After joining the fund, she has borrowed funds to buy more land for growing and raising livestock. After 11 years of hard work, her family now has 2 sao of pomelo trees (approximately 360 square meters). Her trees bring her an income of 2,000,000 VND per month. She would like to borrow 15,000,000 VND to invest in fertilizer and seedlings.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Growing

loans.name: Dao Thi

texts.vi: Chị Đào Thị Cần năm nay 53 tuổi, chồng chị mất sớm hiện tại chị đang sống cùng 1 con trai đã trưởng thành.  Chị Cần tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm  1997, hiện chị là chủ cửa hàng chuyên kinh doanh quần áo tại huyện Kim Động tỉnh Hưng Yên. Nhờ có sự hỗ trợ của con trai nên công việc kinh doanh buôn bán của chị rất thuận lợi và cho thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng.  Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000 để đâu tư mua thêm hàng hóa về bán, mở rộng quy mô cửa hàng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Dap Thi C. is 53 years old. Her husband passed away early and she is now living with one grown up son. Mrs. C. joined TYM Fund in 1997. Currently, she is the owner of a retail store selling clothes at Kim Dong district, Hung Yen Province. With the help of her son, her business has grown and brings her an income of 2,000,000 VND per month. She would like to borrow 10,000,000 VND to invest in more supplies to expand her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi: Chị Phạm Thị D., 43 tuổi. Gia đình chị có ba con và hiện đều còn đang đi học, nguồn thu chính của gia đình chị là từ hoạt động chăn nuôi bò. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2004,  lần đầu tiên khi chị tham gia chị vay 500.000 đồng để chăn nuôi gà, với số lãi thu được đã giúp chị tự tin, mạnh dạn vay mức vốn  cao hơn  để đầu tư phát triển chăn nuôi bò sinh sản. Hiện nay trong chuồng nhà chị có 3 con bò sinh sản mỗi năm chị cũng thu được 10.000.000 đồng tiền lãi từ việc nuôi bò.Chính vì vậy kinh tế nhà chị ngày càng phát triển. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 12.000.000 để đầu tư mua thêm bò về nuôi
texts.en:
Mrs. Pham Thi D. is 43 years old. Her family has three children who are of school age. Her family's main income comes from raising cows. She joined TYM Fund in 2004. Her first loan was 500,000 VND to invest in raising chickens. The profit earned from chicken raising has given her confidence to borrow more loans to invest in raising cattles. Currently, her family has three cows, bringing her an income of 10,000,000 VND. Because of this, her family's economy is gradually improving. She would like to borrow 12,000,000 VND to buy more cows.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Hồng, năm nay 54 tuổi. Gia đình chị có 4 người con và hiện còn đang đi học, nguồn thu chính của gia đình là từ hoạt động kinh doanh buôn bán hàng tạp hoá,  hoa quả của chị và phần lương hưu của chồng với tổng thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000 để mua thêm các mặt hàng bánh, kẹo, và các hàng tạp hóa khác về bán.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi H. is 54 years old. Her family has four children of school age. Her family's main income comes from a store selling convenient goods and fruits. Combined with her husband's pension, her income totals at 2,000,000 VND per month. She would like to borrow 10,000,000 VND to invest in goods such as cookies, candies and other convenient goods for her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Do Thi

texts.vi: Chị Đỗ Thị P., năm nay 54 tuổi ở Kim Động. Nguồn thu chính của gia đình chị là từ chăn nuôi gà, vịt và trồng trọt. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2004. Hiện nay gia đình chị đang chăn nuôi 150 con vịt đẻ, 100 con gà thịtvới thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000 để mua thêm 500 con gà giống, mở rộng quy mô chăn nuôi của gia đình.
texts.en:
This year Mrs. Do Thi P. turns 54 years old. She lives in Kim Dong, Vietnam. The main source of income for her family is from raising chickens, ducks and farming. Mrs. P. has joined TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) since 2004. Currently her family has 150 ducks and 100 chickens, which brings about 2,000,000 VND per month (equivalent to 117 USD per month). She would like to borrow 15,000,000 VND (or 875 USD) to buy 500 breeding cocks, expanding the scope of her farm.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Lav's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Lav C. is the leader for the group loan that has four members. The loan members live in Choup Trav Commune, Siem Reap Province.

Mrs. Lav C., born in 1955, sells Khmer noodles to her neighbors, in front of her house. She started the business more than 5 years ago, and currently earns an average of $2 per day. She is married to Chek Chem (pictured here), 57, who grows and sells vegetables. He also provides a lottery betting service for a commission. He earns an average of $2 a day, which helps purchase food for his family. The couple has eight children, all of whom are single. Two of their children are employed. C. hopes to start a new business raising pigs. Thus she requests a loan to purchase piglets to begin raising pigs.

There are three other members of the group. Ting P., 29, is a widow. She sells Khmer noodles. She requests a loan to purchase piglets to raise.

Haing K., 30, distills wine for sale, and raises pigs from home. K. request a loan to buy a rice mill and begin to provide a service for rice farming.

Sout S. is 25 years old, and sells groceries. She requests a loan to purchase more groceries to store and re-sell. (S.'s husband is pictured here.)

loans.use: Purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Proem

texts.en:
Proem S., 44, lives Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She earns a living by selling groceries from her house, selling items such as cooked food and sweets for kids. She has run this business for a long time. S. is married and currently takes care of two children; both of them are single and are employed. Her husband, Sout Shi, is aged 46, and he sells used clothes in Psakraom Market.

S. works hard every day and is very responsible for her family. The grocery business is S.'s main way of earning an income to support her family. She requests a loan to purchase a variety of groceries to sell. With some of the loan, she plans to purchase a second-hand motorcycle to use for the family's transportation.

loans.use: Purchase a variety of groceries to sell

loans.name: Tep

texts.en:
Mrs. K. is widowed, 45, and lives in Tomnup village in Kandal Province. She sells a variety of food, such as cooked rice with pork, fried potato and banana, and boiled eggs. She has been selling food since 2005 and earns around $4 per day. Her business is going well due to the location near the crowded area, her delicious food, and reasonable prices. She has one son who works selling clothes and earns $5 per day toward supporting the family.

Because of her success and growing business, she needs to expand to increase profits. Therefore, she requests a loan to purchase more meat and raw ingredients to make more food to sell.

loans.use: Purchase more raw ingredients and meat to make more food to sell

loans.name: Yin

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthy, 28, is a tailor in Samky village in Kandal Province, Cambodia. She is married to Mr. Mach and has two young teenagers. Her husband, 34, repairs cars and earns around $10 per day. Mrs. Chanthy buys clothes from villagers in her area to sell, and also sews clothes to sell. Her business is going well, and she earns around $3 per day.

Due to the increasing cost of transportation, Chanthy is requesting a loan to purchase a motorcycle for the family's use, and for capital to purchase more clothes for her business, and to. She said the loan will help to increase her family's income, and make it easier for her husband to go to work and take her children to school.

loans.use: Purchase a motorcycle for the family's transportation, and to purchase more clothes to resell

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey H. was born 1956, is a widow, and lives in Siem Reap province of Cambodia. She earns a living by raising animals like oxen, ducks, and chickens for sale. She also grows vegetables on a plot of land next to her house. She started her businesses over three years ago, and earns an average of $4 each day. She is the good mother of five children; all of them are single. Three of her children are employed; her first child is a motorcycle taxi driver, her second and third children work for a casino. She works hard every day to provide food for her family.

To provide for her family's transportation, H. is requesting a loan to buy a new motorcycle. She plans to use the motorcycle in her business activities. (H.'s son appears in the picture, because she was not available.)

loans.use: Buy a new motorcycle for transportation

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea Y. is 62 years old and a resident of Kompong Cham Province, where she has owned a plot of land since 1980 and makes a living as a farmer. She grows vegetables and flowers, like cabbages and morning glories. She can plant her crops twice per year.

She is married and the mother of five children: three are married and live away from the family home, and two are single and also help her grow vegetables. Her husband works with her in the farming business. Chea Y. works hard at her business activities every day and never wastes time. Growing vegetables is Y.'s main source of income to sustain her family. To help do the hard physical labor of her farming work, Chea Y. is requesting a loan to buy a pump to pump water onto her vegetable crop. She plans to use the remaining amount of the loan to decorate her house. (Y.'s son is pictured, because she was not available.)

loans.use: Buy a pump to pump water onto crops

loans.name: Chhan

texts.en:
Mrs. V., 35, is a rice farmer who lives in Trapeangveng village in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She has been growing rice with her husband since 1989, and her monthly income is KHR4000 ($1) per day. She has three children, all of whom are young teenagers living at home.
